## Functions

```{r}
#| label: showtab-function

# developed with help of chatGPT

show_tab <- function(tab, year, view = interactive(), scrollx_threshold = 6) {
  knitting <- isTRUE(getOption("knitr.in.progress"))

  df <- ptargets |>
    dplyr::filter(
      table == tab,
      year == {{ year }}
    ) |>
    dplyr::select(
      vtype,
      vname,
      marstat,
      incsort,
      incrange,
      ptarget,
      xlcolumn,
      xlrownum
    ) |>
    dplyr::mutate(nxlcolumn = xlcol_to_num(xlcolumn)) |>
    dplyr::arrange(nxlcolumn, xlrownum) |>
    dplyr::select(-nxlcolumn, -xlrownum) |>
    tidyr::pivot_wider(
      names_from = c(xlcolumn, vname, vtype, marstat),
      values_from = ptarget
    )

  n <- ncol(df)
  nr <- nrow(df)

  # Alignment targets (DataTables 0-based)
  # R: 1 right, 2 left, 3..n right
  right_align_js_targets <- c(0, if (n >= 3) 2:(n - 1) else integer(0))
  left_align_js_targets <- 1
  cols_to_fmt <- if (n >= 3) 3:n else integer(0)

  # Horizontal scroll only when table is wide
  use_scrollx <- n > scrollx_threshold

  # Show full height (no vertical scroll); your tables are <= 30 rows
  # pageLength controls how many rows before paging
  page_len <- min(30L, nr)

  tbl <- DT::datatable(
    df,
    class = "display stripe cell-border",
    rownames = FALSE,
    options = list(
      scrollX = use_scrollx,
      paging = FALSE, # <--- show everything (since <= 30 rows)
      pageLength = page_len, # harmless when paging=FALSE, but fine to keep
      autoWidth = TRUE,
      deferRender = TRUE,

      columnDefs = list(
        list(targets = left_align_js_targets, className = "dt-left"),
        list(targets = right_align_js_targets, className = "dt-right")
      ),

      initComplete = htmlwidgets::JS(
        "function(settings, json) {
           var api = this.api();
           var $c  = $(api.table().container());

           if (settings.oScroll && settings.oScroll.sX) {
             $c.find('.dataTables_scrollHeadInner, .dataTables_scrollHead table, .dataTables_scrollBody table')
               .css({'width':'100%'});
             setTimeout(function(){ api.columns.adjust().draw(false); }, 0);
           }

           $c.css({'font-size': '9px'});
         }"
      )
    ),
    filter = "top"
  )

  if (length(cols_to_fmt)) {
    tbl <- tbl |>
      DT::formatCurrency(
        columns = cols_to_fmt,
        currency = "",
        interval = 3,
        mark = ",",
        digits = 0
      )
  }

  out <- htmltools::tagList(
    tbl,
    htmltools::tags$style(
      htmltools::HTML(
        "
        .dataTables_wrapper .dataTables_scrollHead th,
        table.dataTable thead th {
          white-space: normal !important;
          overflow-wrap: anywhere;
          word-break: normal;
          line-height: 1.2;
          vertical-align: bottom;
        }

        th.dt-right, td.dt-right { text-align: right !important; }
        th.dt-left,  td.dt-left  { text-align: left  !important; }

        table.dataTable tbody td,
        table.dataTable thead th {
          padding-top: 2px !important;
          padding-bottom: 2px !important;
          line-height: 1.1 !important;
        }

        table.dataTable thead input {
          padding: 2px 4px !important;
          font-size: 9px !important;
          line-height: 1.1 !important;
          height: auto !important;
          box-sizing: border-box;
        }
        "
      )
    )
  )

  # ---- display logic: Quarto vs interactive ----
  if (knitting) {
    return(out)
  }

  if (isTRUE(view) && interactive()) {
    vfun <- getOption("viewer")
    if (is.function(vfun)) {
      tf <- tempfile(fileext = ".html")
      htmltools::save_html(htmltools::browsable(out), file = tf)
      vfun(tf)
      return(invisible(out))
    } else {
      htmltools::html_print(htmltools::browsable(out))
      return(invisible(out))
    }
  }

  out
}

```

## Examine 2022 values

Because selecting values from several different IRS spreadsheets, from multiple locations in those spreadsheets, could lead to accidentally selecting values that are different from those intended, it's important to compare the resulting data to the intended data. I don't have an automated way to do it, but the tables below make it relatively easy to spot check values.

The sections below show:

- A filterable datatable showing the data that was read from IRS spreadsheets, followed by
- One or more screenshots of intended values, from IRS spreadsheets

Visually spot-check datatable vs. screenshots of totals.

To keep the task manageable, we focus only on 2022 as it is the most important year. This should be updated or extended when new years are added.

Some IRS spreadsheets require multiple screenshots to show all of the columns that are included in the data.
